abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation of the Gabon Natural
            Resources Management Development Policy Loan Project will
            impact on the livelihoods and incomes of those living in or
            near protected areas in general and those living in or near
            national parks in particular. Their access to resources will
            most probably be reduced. This combination resettlement
            process framework and resettlement policy framework
            addresses these problems and outlines mitigations. The
            report identifies the people to be affected (PAPs) and
            assesses their specific needs and interests with the aim of
            restoring their livelihoods. While the report does not yet
            determine whether the project must restore villages, along
            with providing land as compensation. To minimize impacts and
            reduce costs, it may be possible to reform the laws to allow
            human activities in the national parks unless villages
            prefer establishing new sites outside the park. PAPs whose
            livelihoods are entirely based on the park will also be
            provided new income opportunities that are non-land-based
            and guarantee the incomes they had in the pre-park
            situation. People whose livelihoods are only partly based on
            the park will be provided the capacities and infrastructure
            to increase the marketing of their products, and the use and
            maintenance of protection measures against the growing
            animal population in the park, such as community hunting
            zones. Those people who have only traditional rights to park
            and protected area resources may be given cash based
            compensation together with some capacity building to invest
            this. Indigenous people, who depend on park or protected
            area resources will be allowed free access as much as
            possible, including a special right of the Baka people to
            hunt elephants under park supervision. The Baka will also be
            offered social services for free in exchange for a ban on
            commercial hunting on protected species or large scale hunting.
